A number of buildings have been named in Robinson's honor. The UCLA Bruins baseball team plays in [[Jackie Robinson Stadium (UCLA baseball)|Jackie Robinson Stadium]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uclabruins.com/genrel/062200aah.html |title=Steele Field at Jackie Robinson Stadium |accessdate=September 13, 2009 |publisher=UCLA Athletics }}</ref> which, because of the efforts of Jackie's brother Mack, features a memorial statue of Robinson by sculptor Richard H. Ellis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uclahistoryproject.ucla.edu/Fun/ThisMonth_AprRobinson.asp |title=UCLA history project: Robinson statue |publisher=UCLA.edu |accessdate=May 6, 2009}}</ref> City Island Ballpark in Daytona Beach, Florida â the baseball field that became the Dodgers' de facto spring training site in 1947 â was renamed [[Jackie Robinson Ballpark]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.daytonacubs.com/ballpark-jackie.php|title=Jackie Robinson Ballpark
A number of buildings have been named in Robinson's honor. The UCLA Bruins baseball team plays in [[Jackie Robinson Stadium (UCLA baseball)|Jackie Robinson Stadium]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uclabruins.com/genrel/062200aah.html |title=Steele Field at Jackie Robinson Stadium |accessdate=September 13, 2009 |publisher=UCLA Athletics }}</ref> which, because of the efforts of Jackie's brother Mack, features a memorial statue of Robinson by sculptor Richard H. Ellis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uclahistoryproject.ucla.edu/Fun/ThisMonth_AprRobinson.asp |title=UCLA history project: Robinson statue |publisher=UCLA.edu |accessdate=May 6, 2009}}</ref> City Island Ballpark in Daytona Beach, Florida â the baseball field that became the Dodgers' de facto spring training site in 1947 â was renamed [[Jackie Robinson Ballpark]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.daytonacubs.com/ballpark-jackie.php|title=Jackie Robinson Ballpark
|accessdate=April 9, 2009|publisher=Daytona Cubs}}</ref> The New York Public School system has named a middle school after Robinson,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/01/sports/robinson-stood-up-for-what-he-believed.html?pagewanted=all |title=Robinson 'stood up for what he believed' |accessdate=September 12, 2009 |last=Anderson |first=Dave |date=April 1, 1997 |work=The New York Times }}</ref> and [[Susan Miller Dorsey High School|Dorsey High School]] plays at a Los Angeles football stadium named after him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/us/fearing-gang-violence-school-forfeits-a-game.html?pagewanted=all |first=Robert |last=Reinhold |title=Fearing gang violence, school forfeits a game |accessdate=September 12, 2009 |work=The New York Times |date=November 3, 1991 }}</ref> In 1976, his home in Brooklyn, the [[Jackie Robinson House]], was declared a [[National Historic Landmark]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.usatoday.com/sports/2007-07-25-history-sportsites_N.htm |title= Historic sports sites rarely take landmark status |accessdate=October 7, 2008 |work= [[USA Today]] |date= July 26, 2007}}</ref> Robinson also has an [[asteroid]] named after him, [[4319 Jackierobinson]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=4319+Jackierobinson|title=4319 Jackierobinson (1981 ER14)|date=May 11, 2009|publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]|accessdate=September 26, 2009}}</ref>
|accessdate=April 9, 2009|publisher=Daytona Cubs}}</ref> The New York Public School system has named a middle school after Robinson,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/01/sports/robinson-stood-up-for-what-he-believed.html?pagewanted=all |title=Robinson 'stood up for what he believed' |accessdate=September 12, 2009 |last=Anderson |first=Dave |date=April 1, 1997 |work=The New York Times }}</ref> and [[Susan Miller Dorsey High School|Dorsey High School]] plays at a Los Angeles football stadium named after him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/us/fearing-gang-violence-school-forfeits-a-game.html?pagewanted=all |first=Robert |last=Reinhold |title=Fearing gang violence, school forfeits a game |accessdate=September 12, 2009 |work=The New York Times |date=November 3, 1991 }}</ref> In 1976, his home in Brooklyn, the [[Jackie Robinson House]], was declared a [[National Historic Landmark]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.usatoday.com/sports/2007-07-25-history-sportsites_N.htm |title= Historic sports sites rarely take landmark status |accessdate=October 7, 2008 |work= [[USA Today]] |date= July 26, 2007}}</ref> Robinson also has an [[asteroid]] named after him, [[4319 Jackierobinson]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=4319+Jackierobinson|title=4319 Jackierobinson (1981 ER14)|date=May 11, 2009|publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]|accessdate=September 26, 2009}}</ref>
  +   +
== The Republican Party ==
  +   +
The [[Republican National Committee]] released a new website on Tuesday that goes to great lengths to depict the party as open to minority interests. But the GOP may have muddled is message by including individuals who would scoff at today's Republican Party. The inclusion of baseball star Jackie Robinson on the list seems particularly egregious.
  +   +
Writing on page 340 of the autobiography, "I Never Had It Made", Robinson went so far as to insist that he be called an independent, "since I've never identified myself with one party or another in politics."
  +   +
Also in his autobiography, "I Never Had It Made", Robinson Said : By and large Republicans had ignored blacks and sometimes handpicked a few servile leaders in the black community to be their token "niggers."
